Apparent Depth when Looking Through Oil and Water Layers

sidebyside.p: A small light bulb is at the bottom of a tank that has a layer of water and a layer of oil as shown in . Let thickess of the oil layer be 0.4\text{ cm} and the depth of bulb from the surface of water be 2\text{ cm}. Determine the apparent depth of the bulb as seen from near normal. Use a ruler to measure the distance(s).

hint.p: Work on layer at a time.

sidebyside.p:
We can work one interface at a time. Suppose we have only Oil/Water interface. That is the detector is inside oil. Then, we will find that the object will appear at the point \text{Q}_1 with the following relation between the image distance and the object distance from the interface at \text{O}_1.
\text{O}_1\text{Q}_1 = \dfrac{n_2}{n_1}\: \text{O}_1\text{P}. \ \ \ (1)
Now, we take the image \text{Q}_1 as the object for the interface at \text{O}_2O. The refraction will now be between the media with refractive indices n_2 and n_3. Therefore, the final image at \text{Q}_2 will have the following distance.
\text{O}_2\text{Q}_2 = \dfrac{n_3}{n_2}\: \text{O}_2\text{Q}_1. \ \ \ (2)

solution.p:
From (1), (2) and the figure it is readily seen that
\text{O}_2\text{Q}_2 = \dfrac{n_3}{n_2}\: \left[ \text{O}_2\text{O}_1 + \left( \dfrac{n_2}{n_1} \right) \: \text{O}_1\text{P} \right].
Now, we put in the numbers to obtain, the depth of the final image from the surface of oil.
\text{O}_2\text{Q}_2 = \frac{1}{1.2} \left( 0.4 + \frac{1.2}{1.33}\times 2 \right) = 1.84\text{ cm}.
That is, the bulb appears at only 1.84\text{ cm} from the top of the oil rather than 2.4\text{ cm}, the actual depth.

problem.title: Real Image by a Covex Lens followed by a Cocave Mirror

statement.p: A concave mirror of radius of curvature 10\text{ cm} is placed 30\text{ cm} from a thin convex lens of focal length 15\text{ cm} as shown in .
Using algebraic method, find the location and magnification of a small bulb sitting 50\text{ cm} from the lens.

hint.p: Work out image from lens only first and then use that image as object for the mirror.

answer.p: 12\text{ cm} to the left of the mirror, m = \frac{3}{5}.

solution.p:
We first find the intermediate image due to the lens. Let q_1 be the image distance from the lens. We have
f_1 = 15\:\text{cm},\ \ p_1 = 50\:\text{cm},\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ q_1 = \dfrac{150}{7}\:\text{cm} \approx 21.7\text{ cm}.
Since q_1 \gt 0 the intermediate image is to the right of the lens and since q_1 \lt \text{ separation }, the image is to the left of the vertex of the mirror. Now, this intermediate image will serve as the object for the mirror. By using the separation of the mirror and the lens we find the object distance to the mirror to be
p_2 = 30\:\text{cm} - \dfrac{150}{7}\:\text{cm} = \dfrac{60}{7}\:\text{cm}.
The focal length of the mirror is f_2 = R/2 = 5\:\text{cm}; it is positive since we have a concave mirror (recall the sign convention). Therefore, the image distance from the mirror will be
\dfrac{1}{q_2} = \dfrac{1}{5}-\dfrac{7}{60},\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ q_2 = 12\:\text{cm}.
Now, sign convenstion for curved mirrors tells us that q_2 \gt 0 for a mirror means that the image is in front of the mirror. Therefore, the final image at q_2, will be in front of the mirror at a distance of 12\text{ cm} from the vertex of the mirror.
This image will be real image since it forms in front of the mirror as opposed to image behind the mirror.

The net lateral magnification of the image will come from the product of the magnifications in the lens and the mirror.
m = m_1\times m_2 = \left(- \dfrac{q_1}{p_1} \right)\:\left(- \dfrac{q_2}{p_2} \right) = + \dfrac{3}{5}.
Since m\gt 0 the image will be upright, and, since |m| \lt 1 the image will be smaller than the object.

problem.title: Virtual Image by a Cocave Lens followed by a Convex Mirror

statement.p: An object of height 2\text{ cm} is placed at 50\text{ cm} in front of a diverging lens of focal length 40\text{ cm} as shown in . Behind the lens there is a convex mirror of focal length 15\text{ cm} placed 30\text{ cm} from the converging lens. Find the location, orientation and size of the final image.

hint.p: Find the image by the lens first and use that as an object for the mirror.

answer.p: Image 11 cm behind the mirror, m = 0.1, h_i = 0.2\text{ cm}.

solution.p:
We first find the intermediate image due to lens. Let q_1 be the image distance from the lens. We have
f_1 = -40\:\text{cm},\ \ p_1 = 50\:\text{cm},\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ q_1 = -\dfrac{200}{9}\:\text{cm}.
Since q_1\lt 0 the intermediate image is to the left of the lens. Now, this intermediate image will serve as the object for the mirror. By using the separation of the mirror and the lens we find the object distance to the mirror to be
p_2 = 30\:\text{cm} - \left( -\dfrac{200}{9}\:\text{cm}\right) = \dfrac{470}{9}\:\text{cm}.
The focal length of the mirror is f_2 = -15\:\text{cm}, which is negative since the mirror is convex. Therefore, the image distance from the mirror will be
\dfrac{1}{q_2} = \dfrac{1}{-15}-\dfrac{9}{470},\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ q_2 = -11.7\:\text{cm}.
Since q\lt 0 for a mirror means that the image is behind the mirror, the final image at q_2 will be behind the mirror at a distance of 11.7 cm from the vertex of the mirror. This image will be a virtual image since it forms behind the mirror where real rays do not go. The net magnification of the image will come from the product of the magnifications in the lens and the mirror.
m = m_1\times m_2 = \left(- \dfrac{q_1}{p_1} \right)\:\left(- \dfrac{q_2}{p_2} \right) = +0.1.
Since m>0 the image will be upright and since |m|\lt 1 the image will be smaller than the object. The height of the image is given by the product of m and the height of the object.
h_i = m\:h_o = (0.1)(2\:\text{cm}) = 0.2\:\text{cm}.

problem.title: Real Floating Image of a Penny Placed Between Two Concave Mirrors

sidebyside.p: Two identical concave mirrors are placed facing each other with a distance of d=R/2 between their vertices as shown in . One of them has a small hole in the middle. When a penny is placed on the bottom mirror, you observe a real image of the penny floating above the hole.

statement.p: Explain how this happens by showing images in the two mirrors and locate the distance above the mirror with the hole that you will see the floating image. If you like, you can use the following numerical values, R=25\text{ cm}, \Delta = 0.3\text{ cm}.

sidebyside.p: Since the penny is located within a focal distance of mirror \text{M}_1, a virtual image will be formed at q_1, which will serve as an object for mirror \text{M}_2. Now, the object distance p_2 from mirror \text{M}_2 is larger than the focal length, hence image will be a real image at q_2. This is illustrated in . Below, I will work out the distances.

solution.p:
With p=d-\Delta and f=2/R, the image distance q_1 will be
\frac{1}{q_1} = \frac{2}{R} - \frac{1}{d-\Delta}.
Therefore,
q_1 = \frac{R(d-\Delta)}{2d-2\Delta - R} = - \frac{R(d-\Delta)}{2\Delta}.
This will be negative. Therefore, we will get object distance to mirror \text{M}_2 by adding its absolute value to d and using d=R/2.
p_2 = |q_1| + d = \frac{R(d-\Delta)}{2\Delta} + d = \frac{R^2}{4\Delta}.
Now, we work out q_2.
\frac{1}{q_2} = \frac{2}{R} - \frac{4\Delta}{R^2}.
This gives
q_2 = \frac{R^2}{2R-4\Delta}.
Now, this is a little bit beyond mirror \text{M}_1. We can get the distance above the hole by subtracting d from it.
\text{above hole} = q_2 - d = \frac{R^2}{2R-4\Delta} - \frac{R}{2} = \frac{R\Delta}{ R-2\Delta}.
Now, with the numerical values given, we get
\text{above hole} = 0.31 \text{ cm}.
